I hope we continue to safeguard our vulnerabilities for ourselves and each other, away from view of those who don’t know how to maintain material support except in brief spurts, when it’s au courant.

We’ll be fine. This is what POC and especially WOC in America have always known: when it comes to race, we can only count on ourselves and each other. We must expect very little from white people, even dear friends, lest we are so disappointed in them we cannot maintain our bond.

So far, it feels like the only people talking about it on the anniversary are POC, mostly AsAm people, mostly women. Grim and unsurprising that unless we provide a display of gaping psychological wounds for public consumption, there isn’t much interest in supporting our pain.

After the outpouring of support last year after the Atlanta hate crime shooting that killed eight people, six of whom were AsAm women, I was bracing myself for something similar today. Instead I observed something worse:

@ge_ki_tsu Totally! It’s also like, whatever worked for me several years ago before my current therapeutic relationship isn’t going to be what works for me now that I’m in practice

If you meet a therapist who’s a good match, I hope you have the capacity to go HARD with them. I don’t think I would’ve lasted the last two years if I hadn’t, and I’m proud of myself for the work I’ve done and how it supports me in my ongoing work with my own well-being

• How to recognize when someone loses perspective or shifts goalposts without losing my own bearings
• How to trust my own integrity, so I can walk away from interactions knowing someone thinks I’m wrong instead of getting pulled into dynamics that aren’t good for me

• How to recognize my own physiological responses and to read them for the accurate barometer they are of a situation, other person’s intentions, or my own capacity
• How to recognize the line between what I can do and what I can’t do, for myself and others

Some of the biggest things that I’ve learned with my current therapist:

• My boundaries around my well-being are non-negotiable, including for *me*. Even now I sometimes want to bend them bc I want to please whoever I’m talking to. This will affect me very very badly!
If I hadn’t done the work I had in therapy in the years leading up to 2020, I honestly don’t know what shape I would be in right now but it would not be good

Since 2020, nine of my friends have passed away, a family member I was very close to passed away, two mentors who were a major part of my youth passed away, and Bartleby passed away. Many of my friends are currently very sick right now, and a few are in critical condition.

I think I’ve had one major panic attack in the last two years. I used to have 1-2 a day! My mental health isn’t overall improved with everything, but to be honest anxiety has been one of my most debilitating conditions in terms of how it hijacks my present tense
I don’t talk often about my C-PTSD bc it’s pretty private but I am just so grateful right now for deciding to be proactive in my therapeutic work around it

Even though I’ve come a long long LONG way managing my anxiety disorder it’s never totally gone. So thankful for all the work I’ve done with my therapist, esp our somatic work. Otherwise I don’t think I’d know my physiological responses or how to preempt a spiral!

And (this is the most exciting part for me) it's been slower than I hoped, but I should have the complete playkit ready to download for ✨free✨ by the end of next week as well!

Oh shoot I went over my break time, lol. The gist is, please keep sharing about the crowdfund and the game! To help, later this weekend I'll post a handy list of links with press coverage, actual plays, and things like that

There are definitely also gamers! They're just not the majority. I have some ideas about why things shake out this way, but they're interpretations rather than direct observations, so for now I'm focusing on potential fields where #TheSnowQueenRPG could shine

I've noticed that among my most regular players there are a lot of teachers, theater people, writers, outdoor professionals, farmers, students, childcare providers, crafters, visual media artists, and media critics

The majority of my player base are "non games people" who are drawn to the kinds of games I make but don't really identify with ttrpgs or games as like, idk, a core hobby or personal identifier? (Sorry I haven't had coffee yet so this might be sloppily phrased)
This is where I maybe diverge from various friends and colleagues. At this point in the crowdfund, I would love to gain more visibility with potential players who are NOT involved in games

Helping keep #TheSnowQueenRPG consistently visible in various social media feeds, continuing to talk about it in your own spheres, and sharing it with people with personal recommendations help clear both trails.

But who to share it with?

Essentially, there are two big uphill hikes I'm looking at as a creator who's crowdfunding on my own, rather than with K*ckstarter or another crowdfunding platform: the first is visibility, and the second is traffic

The biggest thing you can do to help is spread the word! Sharing the link (https://t.co/3DGlfiDdQ6) with friends or on social media, talking about why you backed the game, or letting journalists who cover this kind of work know about the project goes a HUGE way✨

There's less than $4,000 to go for our second stretch goal, but there's also only 12 days left! Here's what you can do to help #TheSnowQueenRPG hit our next stretch goal and more! https://t.co/XhDp3RER9F https://t.co/QPQwO1Dg5t

What I'm hoping to observe through people sharing their playtests:
• how different prompts dovetail together
• how different global regions' biodiversity impacts prompt options
• how seasonality impacts prompt options
• how migratory patterns impact prompt options

Instead of dice, #YearningRPG uses your real-life observations as its "randomizers." Plants, wildlife, cloud formations, time of day, and especially birds, bird identification, and bird behavior serve as the catalysts for where your character's story goes!
I started writing #YearningRPG last year because of how frustrated I got watching people on my timeline feeding wildlife. This is 100% a project that germinated in the warmth of my spite 🔥
#YearningRPG is a game about destiny, desire, the vast wheeling rhythms of the world, and how sometimes devotion means never bridging the distance between yourself and your true love

— and clean them with a bleach dilution at LEAST once a week. The state is so dry, water is always welcome for birds, water dishes are easier to clean than feeders, and also you get to see them take baths sometimes like what’s not to love??

In California, we have frequent outbreaks of salmonellosis among songbirds, which is often lethal and a threatened species (the Pine Siskin) is particularly susceptible to. I recommend instead leaving out multiple water dishes, far from each other so birds don’t crowd them —

Audubon, state fish and wildlife departments, and the Cornell Lab of Ornithology all have good resources on the considerations to take before committing to a bird feeder! It’s not as simple as “bird feeders bad,” some species benefit from them. But it’s not one size fits all!

People often ask me about bird feeders when I talk about not feeding wildlife. There are many state guides to how to responsibly set up a bird feeder, and part of that includes staying up to date with your state’s status regarding highly contagious avian diseases.
This is the kind of thing people get very defensive about with strangers, but might receive more productively coming from a friend.

If you have friends who feed wildlife pls let them know that wildlife professionals are begging them to stop, bc the animals keep starving once they lose their own foraging instincts, contract diseases we pass on to them, or get euthanized due to how accustomed they are to people

Until those changes occur, if you see me talking about this stuff please tell me to look out my window and ID a bird or go downstairs to water my garden lololol

— and I'm even more bored of talking about them. Until I see the behavior changes I need, from the entities who need to exhibit them, it is no longer something I want to give any parcel of time that makes up my short, finite life in this beautiful world

At this point, I not only feel personally secure in my own integrity, values, and how I made my decisions, I'm also just so fucking bored of these tiny little offerings from companies that are still soaked in the language of plausible deniability —
— I'm sticking to my decision to poke around on my little Squarespace site and keep trying things out on my own

— to funnel untraceable funding into organizations that are working town by town, state by state, and country by country to bring about as much suffering, violence, and death to POC and marginalized groups as they can (cont)

— and 2. provides clear outlines of how they intend to go forward without blockchain integration UNTIL it has been tested, its data vulnerabilities addressed, and maybe figure out how they're going to prevent white supremacist hate groups from co-opting the tech (cont)

— and the company was disingenuous to offer it as a claim to carbon neutrality and they will instead be moving forward with implementable plans to REDUCE WASTE BEFORE IT HAPPENS IN THE FIRST PLACE good lord how long is it going to take to drum that into people whyyyyyyeeee (cont)

Short of a very clear statement from high-level making it clear 1. carbon offsetting/footprint/neutrality is a concept, more or less invented by marketers, that climate scientists agree does far more harm than good and has no guarantee of even working as writ, (cont)
I also kind of hope I never have to talk about KS again lmfaooooooo. It's so boring; I'm so b o r e d with it all

I think it's prudent for people who continue to work with KS or other platforms to make it clear, as I've seen some designers and publishers make it clear, that there is an alternative to supporting their work by offering pre-orders, a parallel inventory, etc etc
— then it is clear to me we run ourselves quite differently, and I wish you the best, and I hope things go well, and I hope you have contingency plans

(cont) still outweighs the many sound reasons to divest from a company that, in the end, will look after its investors long before it looks after its employees, and its employees long before it looks after *you* —

— there is very little reason not to divest once a platform goes directly against the common good when you have less lucrative but nonetheless viable alternatives. If you have that going for you but the short term gain of whatever profit margin you're concerned (cont)

I think that it is exponentially the better decision to gain independence where you can, in the long term, than to gain finite monetary gains in the short term. And, I think if you've worked hard for it and are lucky enough to have a well established audience at present —

But that is the same root of shortsightedness that leads major tech companies, platforms, even individual artists and people to go for scams like N/F/Ts, to put personal trust in blockchain before it's more seasoned and its data risks are better known, to invest in c/r/y/p/to

People are neurologically wired to be way, WAY more responsive to short term decisions, anxieties, and incentives than long term ones. I think that's been especially true lately, when things feel so existentially uncertain in so many different spheres
This also relates to something I said weeks ago, about how a short term loss of revenue or profit margin is meaningless if you make up that difference but lose goodwill in the process

All of these things — creative freedom of expression, long-lived community building within the people who support your work, creating an audience who is flexible and curious about the many directions you might go — are extremely difficult to nigh impossible on a platform
With my own site, I hope that it's a lot easier for people to remember that this is me, one person, making my entire living off of my creative work

I think this is one of the things that crowdfunding platforms do in particular, that is intrinsic to them when you succeed on them. They create a sense of divide, and the artist as a person fades behind a construct of the artist "making it" on a third party crowdfunding platform
I also say it because gross revenue numbers from crowdfunds often create inaccurate, sometimes intensely uncharitable impressions of how an artist lives off that revenue

I say that not as a clout thing, but because people who haven't lived that way, or have experienced it but had safety nets to catch them, don't understand how stark living can be when you live that way and there is nothing below you to break your fall

Only recently are any of them managing to make the kinds of living where they're not looking at their bank account as it dwindles to single digits, wondering if a gig paycheck will come through in time to avoid an overdraft

I'm very lucky to have many close friends who've been working artists for a long time. They have all the same short and medium term stressors anyone has. Many of these friends of mine also have no safety nets outside their art, like me
I say it again, for emphasis: not just one successful project — a whole, varied, multiple-decades-long career.

It is a good, good thing to have people who enjoy and engage with my work and understand that I might make a particular game they personally aren't into, and they will support me anyway because they want me to have a career and they want to support that career

I'm an artist, and a person, whose tastes vary widely and wildly. I've written games that are evocative and beautiful; I'm also writing games that are brutal and baroque. (I think the latter games are beautiful, too! There are more descriptions of guts though)

They are people who will teach you more than I can ever express about artistic growth, community building, what makes art so rewarding and meaningful to make in the first place.

For the most part, I'm not meeting them through Kickstarter.

If you're a creative professional, and particularly if you are an artist, every single person who wants to support you — not just one book or one painting or one game but *you* — is worth their weight in gold. More! SO much more

— and I know that because the sweat and hours I'm investing in this results in a lot of personal correspondence. A lot of people have reached out to me to tell me they're interested, not in a product, not in something a website algorithm showed them, but *me*, as an artist

For one, I think that goal is within reach on my own. I'll have to work harder, but in the end ppl who end up backing the game and supporting me as an artist aren't there because they passively browsed a crowdfund platform and decided this one project looked cool —

To sustain me for that possibility and living costs for the next several months, I need TSQ's crowdfund to make at least $60K in gross revenue. I have no safety net outside my income. And even with all that, I still wouldn't do TSQ on Kickstarter

Without too much detail, I'm in the diagnostic phase of determining why my health has taken some strange turns. My health insurance is expensive, the deductible makes me want to cry, it's possible I'll need the kind of out of network care that runs into five figure bills
I didn't know you were writing for the Financial Times, @hottestsingles! https://t.co/MJakLfUJD1

I have no doubt if I were running #TheSnowQueenRPG on Kickstarter I would be at double the figure I'm at now, maybe more. So what? 

This next part is real life health money talk so if that's not your jam maybe skip ahead a couple posts once this thread is done
Even if someone ends up not backing the game, I still want them to be able to take part in its delight and beauty and joy, and the delight and beauty and joy of the world around us!

How cool would it be to set up the interactive part of #YearningRPG's crowdfund with a "bird of the day" page, or recipes for dandelions (and how to tell them apart from cat's tongue), or how to tell a domestic dog track from [insert wishful thinking wild animal here]?

By way of example, #YearningRPG uses bird, plant, and wildlife identification as its mechanical engine. It's a solo game in a fantasy medieval (for the vibes, not the historical accuracy) setting, and you creat all your NPCs, scenarios, and settings through what is around you irl

I'm already thinking about how I'm going to use my crowdfunding site for #YearningRPG, and #LongRestRPG, and maybe even #TheLuminousDoor if I can create robust fulfillment infrastructure for what could potentially be an unwieldy scale of production for just one person (aka me 😭)
I know I haven't even finished #TheSnowQueenRPG's first week of crowdfunding, but I think in terms of years of planning at once because of how I work, and how much I crave new experiences and lessons

Chapter 15 out of 76. Stephen King, literary legend in his own lifetime, has told one story about his first time ever writing his own stories while recovering from a tonsil removal. It was about half the length of the story about how he one wiped his ass with poison ivy.
Stephen King, one of the most prolific and consistently masterful writers of his genre, has used the word "pus" four times in this book titled "On Writing" and has yet to talk about writing
Stephen King, in an affable avuncular voice: At age five or six I asked my mother if she had ever seen someone die~

@Avonelle Yeah I’m 😶
@Avonelle 🤞🙏

@Avonelle Totally, internal inconsistencies like that are wild and very common and understandable! Let’s hope last year and early this year are just growing pains and there’s more effective messaging around accurate, dispassionate risk assessment this year!
@Avonelle (and also maybe to stop yelling at colleagues on Twitter but that’s a different conversation lmao)

@Avonelle Short of state mandated lockdowns, it doesn’t seem like conventions are going to stop happening, nor are people going to stop attending them, so as far as next steps go I think best practice would be clarity of information and risk assessment

@Avonelle Anyway, this is a much longer and more complicated answer to a yes or no question, but I sincerely hope that I see a shift in messaging for convention organizers this year and in years to come (cont)

@Avonelle This is something that’s been shown time and time again, and I think a great model for its efficacy is in the evolution of implementation in sex education, as well as methods of mitigation within queer communities during the AIDS crisis

@Avonelle As in prior world events that involve high-risk activities in communities that felt very tied to those activities because they were cornerstones of being in community, the best way to approach it from a public health perspective would be to do away with the word “safe” entirely

@Avonelle I also think that the more we continue to stigmatize high risk activities, like large indoor gatherings in winter, the more counterintuitive that language and event logistics will continue to be, bc that stigmatization will continue in to incentivize obfuscation of terms

@Avonelle @JameyHarvey PAXU was a high risk environment (unless ppl are opening windows and leaving doors open for air circulation, in Philadelphia, in December). And again, that is more because of the convention set up than any individual restaurant that any particular group of people went to

@Avonelle Also I’d you haven’t seen it yet, I highly recommend this tool! One of the many many things I like about it is that there a different risk budget calculations, including a high risk tolerance setting. 

https://t.co/KCsepvu1zR

@Avonelle I think, without casting moral judgment on other people’s decisions (not bc they’re blameless, but bc it’s counterproductive), it’s the better practical choice to look dispassionately at the information that is widely available and call things what they are from there
@Avonelle What kind of masks are the diners wearing, and are they leaving them off for the whole meal? How loud are they talking? How far away from you are they? Etc etc.

@Avonelle Even with a restaurant outing, like are the restaurants back doors open? Are the windows open? Do they have a fan and air circulator? Do they have a HEPA filter? What kind of masks are the servers wearing? (Cont)

@Avonelle This was true before Delta or omicron. Now that both those strains are in the picture, I think that conventions as we knew them cannot be thought of as “covid safe.” Doesn’t mean people can’t or shouldn’t go! But I don’t think there should be any illusions about the risk involved

@Avonelle A few months ago I read an interview with a public health communicator who said that people should imagine the transmissibility and lingering capacity of Covid in the air the way they interact with secondhand smoke. I think about how long smoke sits in a room lmao no thank you

@Avonelle None. Doubly none if there’s poor or no ventilation (windows and doors open to the outside with strong circulation currents) and triply none if there are not enough (or no) HEPA filtration air purifiers at work the whole time.

There is only going to be one printing of #TheSnowQueenRPG zine, ever. For real! It is a different text than the game book, and because of the way I’m setting it up it would be impractical to do a second printing. So this campaign is truly the one shot you got!

Pre-launch followers also get access to the “dress rehearsal” of the crowdfund a day before its official launch. Not only does this mean that as a follower you are playing a direct hand in helping me finesse crowdfund project itself, you also get first dibs on the zine!

I forgot to add, there are 30 NPC playbooks total, one for each chess piece on the board plus one per type of piece so players get a choice between three options for the bishop, knights, and rooks, ten options for the pawns, and then two versions of the Kai playbook! https://t.co/49xgruFGdu

also this is the verbal equivalent of throwing salt over my shoulder to keep the devil at bay: my standards for merchandising are *my* standards, designed around "what will help me, jeeyon, sleep at night"

it took me a year and a half to find exactly one (1) place that might be able to make recyclable or compostable/biodegradable sticker sheets and if their quote is in my budget? 100,000% worth it aaaaah FINGERS CROSSED

also i didn't find a place that does all of this, i found a place that makes stickers

just stickers

but fuckinnnn merch? i'm not getting involved unless it meets these specs OR BETTER

and tonight i found a place that is BETTER finally fucking manifested something i've been striving for eyyyyy

there are some game books i might not be able to make with this rubric, depending on the project, and i'll do my best but know that i might need to make concessions depending on [redacted design secrets ooooh]

—  i'm determined to make sure anything i might make is sourced in a way where i won't lie awake at night about all the waste i'm generating during a time of climate disaster and human-driven mass extinction 

you know just some lighthearted small business things :)))))

anyway lmfao THIS is why i haven't done a physical book yet or made merchandise. merch is nice but not like, an essential good or necessity, nor is it art, so —
(cont)

- all products of every type have either plastic-free options manufacturing options or post consumer waste recycled plastic options (curbside recyclable, no less than 90%)
- all printing inks have vegetable-based options (still looking into this but basically no petroleum)

- all textile goods (cotton based) are at least 90% post consumer waste recycled cotton
- all paper goods (non-disposable, like a journal) are at least 90% post consumer waste curbside recyclable
- all packaging material is 100% post consumer waste curbside recyclable
(continued)

- all goods with inherently disposable components are at least 90% post consumer waste curbside recyclable, biodegradable (max 2 month duration), or compostable
- manufacturer provided guide to recycling and/or composting their products
- FSC certified
(continued)
for people curious here is my rubric (perhaps self-explanatory re. every time someone has been like "why don't you make merch tho"):

tfw when you have annoyingly high and annoyingly SPECIFIC standards and specs for product sourcing and you finally, finally find a manufacturer who not only meets but EXCEEDS them? wow wow wow, gonna ask for quotes next week, fingers crossed it works out!!

The link to the campaign page is TBD, but you can follow my Twitter, and the link to The Snow Queen's pre-launch exclusive list is here! https://t.co/BOrnW26uK9

These early efforts are crucial. Help me and other indie creators build up our momentum as we work hard to carve out a semblance of autonomy in a capitalist landscape growing increasingly hostile to individual creators doing their best to live out their values through their work.

You can help me by sharing #TheSnowQueenRPG campaign once it goes live on 2/14, signing up for the pre-launch notification, backing it, recommending it to friends, and sharing it outside of the usual ttrpg circles throughout the campaign run.

I'm going to be making a lot of calls to action in the next month. It might get repetitive, but that's how new habits form, and the new habit of funding creators *directly* is one I'm very invested in helping develop!

Spike Trotman crowdfunded successfully before Kickstarter even existed, and she’s going back to those roots in her plan to divest from the platform. People have done this way before Kickstarter or other platforms. People are doing it without these platforms *right now*.

I’m far from the first creator to crowd fund a project without a platform. Hell, Spike Trotman of Iron Circus Comics spearheaded a lot of what we now consider gospel in a Kickstarter campaign (like contributor bonus stretch goals). I wish she got more credit for it in my circles!

- it is going to be absolutely vital to spread the word through Twitter, word of mouth, and any outlet or personal recommendation that you think will land with sincerity. (Because, and this is a HUGE lesson I learned when I worked retail and sales, it has to be sincere to land!)

But this thread would not have made as much sense if I didn’t make what’s at stake for me clear. To loop things back to the beginning of the thread, it wouldn't have been as clear why, with the hurdles of a lack of internal platform-driven traffic and, lol, everything else -
We tend to be secretive about our financial lives. It feels vulnerable, and people are often inappropriate and invasive in this regard once they sense even a little opening.

I think the thought I want to close on, that I’ve touched on a few times and want to reiterate here and in the future, is not only am I putting my money where my mouth is when it comes to how I'm crowdfunding #TheSnowQueenRPG, I have much more at risk than a lot of people assume.

A8 cont: HOWEVER, I want to give a huge shoutout to Itchio for being one of the scant platforms (along with Gamefound!) to take a hard stance against NFTs in clear, explicit, plainspoken language. You can see it here: https://t.co/leGM6OIG6o

Question 8: “Why aren’t you Itchfunding?”

Answer 8:
• The formatting of the site doesn’t meet my current needs
• The customized CSS needed to adapt a page is beyond my skills and I don’t have the budget for a coder
• Their payouts take about a month to process.

Question 7: “Why aren’t you using Indiegogo?”

Answer 7: I have more questions I’d like to find answers to before I try out the platform (which is very slick!). #TheSnowQueenRPG and the next crowd fund project following it are coming up soon enough that I need more time.

Question 6: “Why aren’t you using Gamefound?”

Answer 6: I’d love to crowd fund a project on Gamefound, and while not set in stone I think it’s likely that I could launch at least one title on their platform this year! However, I won’t be onboarded until April at the earliest.

Answer 5: Even at its current best, proof-of-stake blockchain operations are still far, FAR more energy-guzzling than any already extant transaction that uses fiat currency and Web2 infrastructure. And hilariously (if you're into gallows humor), p-o-s *still uses web2 to run*

Question 5: “But isn’t blockchain (proof of stake) energy efficient? A related variant of this question is, “Why is blockchain getting all this heat when you use credit cards and the internet, which also use up finite natural resources to run their server banks?”

- like Randy Lubin, while there is theoretical benefit to proof of stake blockchain to prove beneficial down the line, its current iterations - including the one KS is proposing to expand operations onto - are a few years away from providing those benefits *at best.*

It will prove to be yet another huge deficit on an already dwindling bank of natural resources.
• Setting aside the environmental aspect, which is quite a big aside, there is no collective public benefit to be gained by these platforms' operational shift to W3.

• Should Kickstarter move forward with their stated plans, Celo or no Celo (a dubious claim to carbon neutrality to begin with) as the current tech stands there is no way they can operate without negatively impacting the environment at great cost, due to their scale.
• Normalizing these three forms of *needlessly* wasteful technology, on any scale, does further damage regardless of whether a company is currently implementing them or plans to in the future.

It is not alarmism to recognize the signs of a wide-scale speculative bubble, and say so. Blockchain might not be an outright scam the way NFTs are, and crypto is somewhere in the middle, but the way all three are indelibly intertwined at present makes me extremely wary.

• I live in the Bay Area, California, a general urban area that has seen several cycles of bubble-and-bust nestled within a state that whose history is perhaps most famous for the Gold Rush. You can imagine what the 2008 housing crash --> Great Recession was like here.

A4 cont:

A2 cont: That's how that lands to me. I won’t bother spending time on why it’s fruitless, I think you can either see why it’s a fallacy, or you’re entrenched/defensive enough about it for your own reasons, and that’s between you and your therapist/priest/group chat/whatever.

A2 cont: To the other point, I do not see any constructive avenue out of an argument that says “well if you want to avoid inflicting this kind of damage, why aren’t you ✨🙏pure🙏✨ in every other sector of your life where you already do or potentially could?”

A2 cont: For the first part, I don’t need Kickstarter to live *if my independent projects succeed.* That's another big reason I'm taking this huge risk: I want the data. I want to make my own observations, based on my choices and actions. I want to prove we can thrive this way!

A2 cont: Sub in "disingenuous," "bad faith," or lmfao "gaslighting" (????) for "hypocritical" and you'll get a decent survey of the kinds of accounts I've been assiduously muting or blocking over the last few weeks.
A2 cont: It is sometimes implicitly (or explicitly lmao) accompanied by some version of the question, “Isn’t it hypocritical to divest from X when you frequently use Y and Z?”
Answer 2: This is an amalgamated summary of many different versions of the same question that I’ve seen, which is “Why are you divesting from X platform but not Y platform?”

Question 2: “There’s almost no platform left that doesn’t accept or make their own cryptocurrency, manage their operations on blockchain, or enable the minting and selling of NFTs. Why bother divesting from Kickstarter when you're still on Twitter/PayPal/etc?”

- a transition like this is one among many, many seasons, and that I will be able to learn from it, and that those lessons will teach me how to grow.

And, I have faith in my players and readers, who have shown me time and time again why I do this work at all.

Q1 cont: I have faith. I have faith in myself, my work, my drive, my resourcefulness, my integrity. I have faith in my collaborators and peers, I have faith in my creative field, and I have faith that if nothing else, in the span of a long-lived artistic career -

- vulnerability that a more fully realized move to Web3 presents. (I'll reference this video again, but if you haven't watched "Line Goes Up" by Dan Olson on YouTube, please watch it. It's incredibly well researched and addresses every single possible defense of Web3)

Q1 cont: My intuition and observation tells me that people who are using platforms turning to NFTs, blockchain, or cryptocurrency are gambling that they won’t see diminishing returns on investment by staying through audience attrition, lingering bad PR, or the infrastructural -
Q1 cont: This isn’t a moral judgment. As has been pointed out many times, it’s unfair to place the full weight of blame on the shoulders of independent artists for decisions a platform is making.
Q1 cont: But to be frank, because of these platforms' bald, unrepentant greed, no matter what decisions we make we’re *all* making a gamble.

Q1 cont: I'm very risk averse. I've never taken out a major loan. I've never been drawn to gambling. This feels like a huge gamble; and it is, technically, a gamble, because the success of this project is not only unassured, according to the current numbers it’s also unlikely.
Q1 cont: This is just context for why it is not an exaggeration on my part to say that I am staking everything I have on my faith in myself to make a living according to my values, as best I can.

Q1: I’m sharing that not to leverage pity or sympathy, and I strongly prefer ppl back my work because they like my work or overall body of work and want to invest in that project and/or my continued creative career, full stop

Q1: This is not where I expected to be, and that’s part of life. My “big buffer” funds were spent in the months immediately after my grandmother’s, then my cat Bartleby’s deaths, and to address growing concerns with my own health. These things happen, and I don't resent it.

Q1 cont: What that means is if I fail not only to meet that funding goal, but exceed it by a wide margin, there will be nothing left for insurance, internet, food, utilities, taxes, nor any other expenses, starting in March.

Q1 cont: The funding goal is just that, as it always is: the minimum amount to pay for a minimum viable project and the time I’ve spent working on it. I've considered raising the amount, but I want my funding goals to always represent what the project entails, no more, no less.

Q1 cont: It wasn’t until my *third* successful crowd fund that I was able to afford health and dental insurance. If The Snow Queen and the next project I launch fail, I will nominally be able to cover rent with my other earnings, just barely, and *that’s it.*

Q1 cont: The phrasing is melodramatic, but the facts are stark and unadorned. It wasn’t until I started crowdfunding games that I was able to afford my basic costs of living and the cost of paying my taxes annually (rather than having them taken out of my paycheck on a W2).

Question 1: “What do you have at stake?”

My entire life.

The reason I’m not saying “livelihood,” “income,” or “career” is because in this case, I think those terms obscure what I am funding with this project and projects to come: my literal ability to live.

This thread is likely to get pretty long, and pretty direct, as fair warning.
If you will indulge me for a moment, please imagine taking a 60%-70% income loss and imagine how that would affect your health, housing, and emotional well being before reading further.
Backers aren't a perfect parallel to income, but the percentages were startlingly similar on these two projects. On Gideon Blythe, 36% of gross earnings came from external traffic; on TSOS, 39%.

The Shape of Shadows is even more stark. Of the 1,318 backers, 416 supported the project coming in from external traffic. That's a similar percentage, at 31.5%, but TSOS had several contributors on it. Backers for this project weren't just paying me, they were paying the team
*backer loss, not income loss — don't worry, we'll get there lmao

Of the 963 backers on Gideon Blythe, only 308 came from external traffic. That may sound like a lot, but that is 32% of the backer total - meaning if #TheSnowQueen reflects that percentage, I will be taking a 68% income loss. SIXTY-EIGHT PERCENT.

I ran the numbers last night comparing how many backers for my two solo Kickstarter project campaigns came from external traffic. The first is The Last Will and Testament of Gideon Blythe, which had 963 backers. The second is The Shape of Shadows, which had 1,318 backers.

That means that every single person who goes to the site, and every single person who backs the project, will be coming from external traffic sources. That could be Twitter, the pre-launch notification list, or you sharing the page directly with someone.

Here's why that's scary:

I am independently crowdfunding #TheSnowQueenRPG. I'm not using Kickstarter, Indiegogo, Itchio, Gamefound, or any other platform with its own internal algorithm bringing people browsing the platform to my project. TSQ's crowdfund page is a website I'm setting up on Squarespace.

There are only seven days* left until #TheSnowQueenRPG's crowdfunding goes live!This is the final stretch of pre-launch, and I want to explain why this project, and my income, will live or die on how much you (yes, you!) share the game from now until its completion. 🧵 https://t.co/CAOCLh3tYy

For those of you who read through the whole thread, thanks for letting me be a little self indulgent on the timeline 💖

If you haven't signed up for the pre-launch notification yet, and this thread piqued your curiosity, here's the link!
https://t.co/BOrnW26uK9

I've been pretty tightly focused through the development of this project campaign in what I'm sharing: here's the game, here's the sign up, please share the link, etc. But this week the process is tapping in to deeper roots. I try to pay attention when I feel that happening.

But "independent" doesn't mean "alone." It's a common cultural fallacy, in America, to conceptualize survival as an act of rugged individualism but lololol no, that is. Not viable.

You need a village not just to survive, but to thrive.

Doing this independently, with NO crowdfunding platform, NO internal foot traffic, NO algorithm, just a Squarespace template and a load of new ideas, feels a bit like the bus is late, we lost a site, and I have to teach people how to make a fire without actually making a fire

I think there's a reason my mind keeps going back to these memories from my last job, because those situations were very complex, with tons of new variables and stressors, and we managed it every ding dang season, with good humor and camaraderie and a lot of meaningful teamwork
"Fire season starts in May now, time to teach summer campers how to build a fire WITHOUT ACTUALLY BUILDING A FIRE"

"We are still in the midst of getting permitting permissions for one of the sites we hinged like 50% of our programming on so I guess it's TIME TO COMPLETELY REDESIGN SUMMER PROGRAMMING FOR MY DEPARTMENT ON THE FLY"

But also, I remember the times at work when like, "one of our 84 passenger buses is going to be an hour late so now it's time to entertain ~100 children enough that they don't get anxious about it SURPRISE, JEEYON"
- "scrambling to build a raft with bits and pieces of the ship I was riding in, that just blew up"

I was chatting candidly with a good friend earlier, who said, "You're blazing a new path forward, which is extremely kickass but also extremely scary!" and I was like I'm so heartened to hear that this is blazing a new path forward, bc what it feels like is more like-

Moving off K/ickstarter is, at its heart, an environmental shift. Like learning to engage and connect meaningfully with the outdoors and the world, I can't control the environment around me or what it does, but I've learned (or will learn) the skills to adapt to systemic change

This feels different because to my lizard brain can't hook on to anything tangible in this process yet. Figuring out how to crowdfund this game feels like trying to weave a rope out of thin air and then whoops turns out that rope is MY LITERAL LIFELIFE lfmao OOPSIE

At my last job, because there were so many moving parts and everything was constantly shifting because nature - beautiful, irreplaceable, vital - straight up does not give a fuck about your plans, adapting to environmental shifts became second, uh, nature

All the new ideas I'm introducing in the crowdfunding structure and the game itself are starting to make my brain sizzle. I feel like I haven't spent this long in an ideating stage in years, not since my last job where we had to adapt daily, sometimes hourly, to changes in nature

As of last night, we’re at 750 subscribers for the pre-launch notification of #TheSnowQueenRPG - that’s 75% of my hopeful total of 1K! Closer and closer by the day! 🤍🤍🤍🤍

As a refresher for what I mean by a bad day, I’ve link to a previous thread talking about executive dysfunction and how it plays a role in my disability https://t.co/ereXh41Ef5

People who count it as a point of pride that they don’t make many typos and actively judge other people for making them, especially in casual communication, are bad vibes, just not my jam. Winnowing that out in myself and my social circles helped a *lot *

A big part of using voice to text in my day to day, esp on bad days, was learning to get over my embarrassment around typos and grammatical syntax, and frankly I now find that tendency to be REALLY unappealing in other people, let alone myself

It kind of sucks to know that I was flaky on earlier stuff, but it’s been helpful to resist carrying unproductive shame around a disability accommodation that I didn’t know about. It doesn’t change that I biffed stuff I wish I’d hit, but now I know!

A couple years ago people would ask me for short messages or blurbs or whatever and I would either lose track of them or get stymied and end up not being able to be helpful. Recently, a friend asked me for a blurb and I was able to voice dictate it into our chat app as we spoke

When I say platforms what I mean is text messaging on my phone, email (every account equals one platform as far as the way my mind seems to organize it), chat apps where again every different app equals one platform, social media, and so on

I really wish I had started using voice to text dictation year sooner. For whatever reason, when I’m having high executive dysfunction it’s really challenging to consistently answer text obligations, and the more platforms I have to take into consideration the harder that gets.

But I didn't see a happy ending, at any point since I decided not to use KS through to today. I've been banging my head against the wall of trying to bolster the weak points of building a project like this, and with additional constraints I didn't anticipate.

3. While daily countdown tickers and supporter growth charts can also be custom coded into Squarespace templates, it's unwieldy, and because I don't understand it I can't grapple with how to solve it.

I want to say here: this thread has a happy ending

2. Supporters' payments will be taken up front, rather than once the project is fully funded, and there isn't a satisfactory way to create a single consolidated visualization of many granular transactions.

1. The progress bar, that exciting marker of how much a project has funded in the very moment you're looking at the site, takes custom coding on Squarespace, and the templates don't lend themselves well to it.
The coding and web design skills it takes to make a basic crowdfunding page are far, far beyond me, and there are three specific things that I simply can't do at my current comfort zone:

So far, everything related to the web-related aspects of making my own crowdfunding project has been WELL beyond two zones of proximal development; and just like any kid who wants to build a fort but hasn't figured out what kind of sticks to use or where to put them, I floundered

As your skills grow, your proximal zones of development - the concentric circles that touch yours as you go outward - become larger and larger, and along with growing your skills, you also grow confidence, self-assurance, etc etc

If someone is challenged just enough that they can feel themselves stretching their own abilities and skills, but not so far that the gap seems unbridgeable, you make far more progress than if you try to adhere to more rigid standards that shove someone too far across the gap

If you imagine a series of concentric circles, and your comfort zone regarding one skill as the center, It's more effective to try to coax someone one, maybe two, zones of development out from that center of comfort than it is to push them further

There's an educational theory I learned for my last job called "proximal zones of development." You can find a lot about it online, but the basic idea is a visualization of how motivation, learning, and perseverance are fostered and set up for best possible success
